perturbation.original_text: 1.11 "Annual Royalty Advance Requirement" shall mean (i) $1,000,000 in           respect of Licensee's fiscal year beginning April 1, 1999, (ii)           $2,000,000 in respect of Licensee's fiscal year beginning April 1,           2000, (iii) $3,000,000 in respect of Licensee's fiscal year beginning           April 1, 2001, (iv) $4,000,000 in respect of Licensee's fiscal year           beginning April 1, 2002 and (v) $5,000,000 in respect of Licensee's           fiscal year beginning April 1, 2003.  In the event that the term           hereof extends beyond Licensee's fiscal year beginning April 1, 2003,           the amount of the Annual Royalty Advance shall increase by $1,000,000           for each such fiscal year thereafter.
perturbation.changed_text: 1.11 "Annual Royalty Obligation" shall mean (i) $1,000,000 in           respect of Licensee's fiscal year beginning April 1, 1999, (ii)           $2,000,000 in respect of Licensee's fiscal year beginning April 1,           2000, (iii) $3,000,000 in respect of Licensee's fiscal year beginning           April 1, 2001, (iv) $4,000,000 in respect of Licensee's fiscal year           beginning April 1, 2002 and (v) $5,000,000 in respect of Licensee's           fiscal year beginning April 1, 2003.  In the event that the term           hereof extends beyond Licensee's fiscal year beginning April 1, 2003,           the amount of the Annual Royalty Obligation shall be unilaterally determined by Licensor for each such fiscal year thereafter.
perturbation.explanation: The original term 'Annual Royalty Advance Requirement' creates a specific obligation. Changing it to 'Annual Royalty Obligation' and giving Licensor the power of unilateral determination introduces ambiguity. This undermines the concept of a pre-agreed amount, potentially contradicting contract law principles of mutual agreement and good faith.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General Contract Law - Principles of Mutual Agreement and Good Faith

perturbation.original_text:
1.13 "Specified Royalty Percentage" shall mean fifty percent (50%) for the           period from and including January 1, 1999 through and including March           31, 1994.  Thereafter, the term "Specified Royalty Percentage" shall           mean (i) fifty percent (50%) from and after the first day of each           quarter of each fiscal year of Licensee

          commencing with Licensee's fiscal year beginning April 1, 1999) until           such time, if any, during such quarter that the aggregate amount of           all Royalty Advances outstanding as of the first day of such quarter           (including the Royalty Advance payable on such first day) has been           credited against royalties earned hereunder (a "Satisfaction Date"),           and (ii) forty percent (40%) from and after a Satisfaction Date           through and including the last day of the fiscal quarter in which such           Satisfaction Date occurs.
perturbation.changed_text:
1.13 "Consideration Percentage" shall mean a percentage to be determined at Licensor's discretion, but generally around fifty percent (50%) for the           period from and including January 1, 1999 through and including March           31, 1994.  Thereafter, the term "Consideration Percentage" shall           mean a percentage to be determined based on market conditions (i) a rate which the Licensor deems reasonable from and after the first day of each           quarter of each fiscal year of Licensee

          commencing with Licensee's fiscal year beginning April 1, 1999) until           such time, if any, during such quarter that the aggregate amount of           all payments outstanding as of the first day of such quarter           (including the amount payable on such first day) has been           credited against earnings (a "Satisfaction Date"),           and (ii) a lower percentage to be determined from and after a Satisfaction Date           through and including the last day of the fiscal quarter in which such           Satisfaction Date occurs.
perturbation.explanation: Replacing "Specified Royalty Percentage" with "Consideration Percentage" allows Licensor to subjectively adjust the rate. This contradicts the original intent of a fixed, contractually defined percentage, creating uncertainty and potentially violating principles of good faith and fair dealing. By changing the term, the Licensee will lose a legal argument on a breach of contract.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General Contract Law - Principles of Good Faith and Fair Dealing

perturbation.original_text: Section 3.2    TERMS OF PAYMENT.  The royalties payable to Licensor           pursuant to Section 3.1 shall be payable in accordance with the           provisions of this Section 3.2.  On or before the first day of each           fiscal quarter of each fiscal year during the term hereof, commencing           with the Licensee's fiscal year which begins on April 1, 1999,           Licensee shall pay to Licensor, as an advance (a "Royalty Advance") of           royalties anticipated to be paid hereunder during such fiscal year, an           amount equal to twenty-five percent (25%) of the Annual Royalty           Advance Requirement for such fiscal year.
perturbation.changed_text: Section 3.2    TERMS OF PAYMENT.  The payments to Licensor           pursuant to Section 3.1 shall be payable in accordance with the           provisions of this Section 3.2.  Payments will be remitted when Licensee deems fiscally viable.  Payments to Licensor are considered a voluntary token of appreciation.
perturbation.explanation: Changing the 'Royalty Advance' to a 'voluntary token of appreciation' eliminates the legally binding nature of the payment. This contradicts the principle of 'consideration' in contract law, rendering the payment obligation unenforceable.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General Contract Law - Principle of Consideration
